That's going to put a lot of downward price pressure on the smallsat launchers, and few will have the margins to survive. 25:55 Astra’s Rocket 3.0 is significantly cheaper but has much less payload than Rocket 4, which would be the claimed launch vehicle here, albeit with Firefly Reaver engines and, eventually, Astra’s in-house designed variant, should they not be looking into buying any more from Firefly.

As for ABL’s GS0 portable launch system: unlike Astra, who provides it as a service to their own launch vehicle, GS0 seems designed to be used by other rockets not made by ABL. Basically, it’s a launch site for sale. Anything that can run on Kerolox (including RP-1 and Jet-A) or Methalox can be launched by this system, and for the Rocket to be compatible, it must have those fuels, have a dry mass of 7000 lbm and a wet mass of 150000lbm at liftoff (so a dry mass of 3,175kg and wet mass of 68,039kg, respectively). This means, hypothetically, all the equipment required to move the rocket itself and the launch site can also be used to launch Firefly Alpha, and with some upgrades, Relativity’s Terran 1 and Phantom’s Laguna. It can be modified to work with any small lift Rocket, meaning other companies can get more launch sites to work with, and thus can be customers with ABL.

4:42 you're wrong in your logic, there. It WON'T matter when starship is build and operating. Your analogy with the semi-truck and the scooter falls short when the semi-truck would be far CHEAPER than the scooter. I'm surprised you don't seem to have thought this through, while it's quite easy to grasp. With starship EVEN if you only paid for one mini-satellite on a dedicated flight, you'd only need to pay for the fuel costs, as it's fully reusable. A small launch rocket won't be able to do that. Fuel would set you back maybe $200000, while the cheapest small launcher would still cost you $2000000!

And this will remain true until the point they can create small launchers that are cheaper then just the fuel of a bigger launcher...which is extremely unlikely, since you always have to throw away at least the upper stage. So, in your analogy, it would be like paying for the fuel of the semi-truck, or paying for the fuel of the scooter AND the scooter itself every time you order something. That's nearly impossible to be advantages for the scooter. Surely you see the logic of this reasoning?

I have a question that maybe someone with knowledge may answer. The Newton's third law says that that the faster the exhaust, the more push. The exhaust speed in a combustion engine is limited by the temperature the materials can withstand. But nowadays we have very powerful magnets. Why don't we use magnetic fields to hold a very high temperature plasma so, the exhaust's speed is multiplied some order of magnitude? We can heat up hydrogen to the hundreds of millions of degrees and confine it in a magnetic chamber in fusion experiments. Even a fracion of a fraction of that temperature should be more than enough to outperform the current speeds. If we manage to make the exhaust go x10 faster, it means you will need x10 times less flow to get the same impulse, which means, you need x10 times less fuel to get the same payload to orbit or, you can keep the engines running x10 times longer. As someone who was sort of in the satellite industry almost 2 decades ago; did my post graduate as part of a university program that designed and built 2 LEO micro-satellites and was involved in a couple of other commercial satellites.

The launch procurement process were as follow: in the 90s and early 2000s you beg and borrowed to scrounge up enough money and then go make presentation to either NASA or Roscosmos to be included as secondary or tertiary payload on a launch. You then HOPEFULLY get a slot or wait for months or even year or 2 until one becomes available for an orbit maybe halfway acceptable for your design, then it is another year or 2 to actually wait for the launch. Most of the time you will have to settle for suboptimal orbit that cut down on your satellite design life as much as 50%.

That same money now pays for more than 50% of a RocketLab launch or a complete projected cost of an Astra launch. So it truely is a game changer especially since the technology advanced so mist during this time making satellites a few orders cheaper, smaller and more capable.

Question - Could Starlink be good for Preventing a Kessler syndrome scenario? The Starlink Constellation is in an active lifecycle that regularly de-orbits its satellites, even if some fail to de-orbit themselves they are designed to 'drag' quickly and re-enter the Upper atmosphere passively. In their wake in Low Earth Orbit they preset "cleaned up" paths in which they were potential targets for small debris like bolts and untracked small objects. wouldn't their wake paths present "Safe Zones" for other transiting space craft and actually "Actively" intercept untracked debris? Even if they don't "take a bullet" for humanity, at least they would "pathfind" Safe Zones for human occupied spacecraft. Autonomous Robo-cleaners of the skies.

personally I love all the different approaches and am in thrall to the engineering solutions.
but, in economic terms, I have to admit I shudder at the whole marketplace.
I see the car industry of the last 100 years being rolled into one massively time-compressed,
flailing enviroment.
it seems that the modern, 'competitive' arena isa world away.
people took scientific ideas and tried 'stuff'. then 'stuff' became ideas that only rich people could afford
and with a lot of messy machinations both in engineering and marketplace, became where we are today.
not that I'm saying 'competition' is a bad thing, just that it is not a good starting point.
well, actually, I'm saying that the hypernormal ideal of competition at the retail end, that you have to beat the crap
out of everyone else as much as possible, is a bad idea.
it's bad for all sorts of reasons. the first is that it takes another hypernormal idea, unlimited downside risk,
and adds it into the mix.
everyone, as a result, has to build the complete pacakge, from scratch, with some kind of quirk
that might give them the competitive edge.
that is catastrophic, economically.
talking of price, one of the market indicators we all love, and you use here, which is fair enough,
surely we have to differentiate a bit between the Elons/Bransons of this world and everyone else.
and yes, I know they aren't funding it all out of their own pockets etc etc, but, for example,
if you look at Falcon One, what was the point in that?
clearly, if the 'price' (in terms of normal economic metrics, like cost with profit margin) was 'right'
then, either it should still be flying, or, at least the tech leased out (engines if nothing else).
for a business not to, is insane.

I found this channel a while ago (the space suit wearing days) and to be perfectly honest I did find his enthusiasm a bit over the top (and a bit annoying, at first).

But I kept watching and I realised that Tim is as genuinely super enthusiastic in all things rockets and space, as he appears.

It is absolutely amazing the amount of knowledge he has and the huge amount of research he does for each video (e.g. the video comparing various different rocket engines springs to mind)

The respect he has gained from other YouTubers (who have referenced his channel) and others (such as Elon Musk) shows how knowledgeable and great video maker he is.

The fact that one of the most in demand people on the planet for interviews by huge media corps (Elon Musk) has taken the time to speak to Tim, multiple times, speaks volumes.
Musk has even been seen wearing one of the T-shirts Tim sells.

In addition, not only did a planned interview with Musk occur before the first crewed Dragon launch (the most important moment in his company's history and a first in space exploration) but the Director of NASA also decided to take the time to join Musk unexpectedly for the interview as well!

His videos are super informative and he makes even something as complicated as the Falcon 9's Merlin Rocket Engine easy to understand through his explanation and use of graphics. And the music (which he composed) is also great.

Seriously, Tim could easily get a job as a space technology reporter with any major newspaper or TV station but thankfully we have him here on YouTube.

I hope his channel continues to grow, inform and educate. YouTube need more channels like this :)

Skyrora is not the first rocket to use RP1 and HTP as the fuel and oxidizer combination. Britain's BLACK ARROW launch vehicle from the late '60s & early '70s used the exact same two propellants, in the exact same engine-cycle, decomposing the HTP to run the turbine that drives the turbopumps. (and yes, the official spelling of BLACK ARROW specified that it was to be spelled using all-caps, I'm not shouting) Moreover, BLACK ARROW's specifications made it, by the definition you outlined in the beginning of this video, a Small-lift Launch Vehicle, by today's standards.

I'd separate them into two sub-categories <500kg and >500kg

Of the <500kg sector: Electron is still the king, unless Astra's Rocket can get up and running reliably and quickly. While Launcher One has some niche benefits, I think the risks and costs of having your launch platform be a 747 with people on board (as opposed to a static pad) are going to keep it from getting a decent market share. But we'll just have to see.

Of the >500kg sector: That's a tougher game to call. The Terran-1 is a complete unknown, but could prove to be a huge disputer to the market if it's reliable and cost effective. Even if's it's not, their Stargate tech has many applications in other areas which will allow them to pull in revenue elsewhere (imagine owning a sports car built by a rocket company, for example).
Firefly looks like a the worst of the bunch on paper, but having a rocket on the pad now is a significant milestone if you are an investor or a customer looking to get a payload on orbit.

That being said, this is all purely speculation, and anything could happen. Building a successful orbital-class rocket is hard. Building a successful orbital-class rocket company is much, much harder. Rocket Lab's recent failures show that even the undisputed leader of small sat launch companies still has a tough road ahead of them.

2021-2022 is going to be interest to watch however it all plays out. And I for one, am here for it. :D

The obvious key match-ups.

1. Astra vs ABL - both trying to do "launch from anywhere" - surely even if the competition is viable there's not room for more than one
2. Launcher One vs the market - either air launch is useful or it's not. If it is then why isn't Pegasus flying. Will be interesting to see
3. Electron vs Terran 1 - honestly has the same strategy (standard rocket infrastructure and launch pads). If 3D printing works Electron is maybe in trouble IMO. If not, Terran 1 is in trouble.

There are many others in the 3rd category - notable Orbex and Skyrora.

But of course most missions could go on any of them. So it really will be about cost vs speed/reliability and where the market draws the line.

It will be interesting to see if:

1. Neutron gets off the ground before the new competitors eat Electron's market
2. Neutron gives Rocket Lab lots of launches (which lowers the per Electron-launch cost for their business because it'll share teams and infrastructure).

Regarding the closed-cycle HTP skyforce engines - the concept is actually pretty old, and has skin in the smallsat game from decades ago! The British gamma engines used on the Black Knight sounding rocket (which, weirdly, got its own suite of SSLV conversion proposals in the early days) used the exact same technique, actually flying before the first staged combustion engine, the S1.5400. Later variants of the gamma were also used on the Black Arrow, the cancellation of which is a great example of the mentioned nature of integration and operation costs not scaling linearly with the rocket, though there was also competition with the preexisting American Scout, also an early smallsat launcher.

I don't think we'll have many small sat launchers in 10 years. Maybe one will remain. The reason is simple: Starship, and future potential Starship competitors. It's obvious that full reusability is where it's at in terms of cost and cadence, and in order to make that work in terms of mass is large vehicles.

A fully and rapidly reusable super heavy lift rocket changes everything. Scheduling is no longer an issue, and the specific orbit issue is solved by kick stages.

So, where do I see a market for small sat launchers? Well, I see them getting rid of their 1st and 2nd stages, and developing instead common satellite buses, easy payload integration, and 3rd/kick stages. Starship launches with a bunch of small sats into a common low orbit, then each uses a kick stage to achieve its desired altitude and inclination. That will eventually be unbeatable both in terms of cost and cadence.

Feel like this video is missing a critical piece of this and that is an examination of the business cases for these rockets and if it is still solid.

My impression is that a huge portion of the business case for many was made before ride share became common. You essentially had one class of potential customers before that. People with sats too small for a traditional launch.

Now that is cut in two or three slices. There is now a way to loft those satellites more cheaply thru ride share. Your market is cut to a percentage of that that needs a specific orbit or a specific timeframe as you say. But the most interesting examination would be what percentage of this market is that?

The point being SpaceX gobbled up a ton of those dollars and what I suspect is well north of 50% of the small sat market. Rocket Lab is knee deep in the business case and suddenly decides it needs a new rocket? Not a coincidence in my book.

I would be surprised if more than 2 of these systems survive very long.
